issue.title: Skipping indirection is not allowed for function_ref

discussion.p: Currently the wording in allows implementation to avoid double indirection when constructing owning functions wrappers from another one:

blockquote.p: -2- Let t be an object of a type that is a specialization of function, copyable_function, or move_only_function, such that the target object x of t has a type that is a specialization of function, copyable_function, or move_only_function. Each argument of the invocation of x evaluated as part of the invocation of t may alias an argument in the same position in the invocation of t that has the same type, even if the corresponding parameter is not of reference type.

discussion.p: However, the wording does not cover a function_ref, disallowing implementation to perform this optimization when signatures are compatible, for example:

We should include function_ref in the list. Note that this allows, but does not require, an implementation to perform such an optimization. As a consequence, it is acceptable to specify the allowance for all combinations of polymorphic wrappers, even for creating an owning wrapper from a non-owning one, where implementing such an optimization may not be possible.

blockquote.p: -2- Let t be an object of a type that is a specialization of function, copyable_function, or move_only_function, or function_ref, such that the target object x of t has a type that is a specialization of function, copyable_function, ormove_only_function, or function_ref. Each argument of the invocation of x evaluated as part of the invocation of t may alias an argument in the same position in the invocation of t that has the same type, even if the corresponding parameter is not of reference type.

discussion.note: 2024-05-21; Tomasz's comment and upates proposed resolution
discussion.p: After implementing double indirection avoidance in the libstdc++, I have realized that above wording change is insufficient to cover all user observable effects of the change. Revelant quote from the Avoid double indirection in function_ref from libstdc++ mailing lists:

blockquote.p: To avoidance of double indirection requires that constructed function_ref, refers directly to the target function of the source, instead of source, and this is visible after the assigment:
While we may want to allow skipping indirection for function_ref, as this produces same behavior as in case for copy constructor (matching signatures):
I do not think this is acceptable for move_only_function. …
Note that for the same reason, implementations are not free to avoid dangling when constructing function_ref from reference_wrapper:
Note that this is limited to function_ref due reference nature of this wrapper.

discussion.p: The updated resolution allows indirection but making it unspecified if function_ref constructed from other function_ref specialization, will refer to source object or its target.
Set priority to 2 after reflector poll.
Strong oposition to making it unspecified whether function_ref constructed from other function_ref will reference source object or its target directly.

blockquote.p: -2- Let t be an object of a type that is a specialization of function, copyable_function, or move_only_function, or function_ref, such that the target object x of t has a type that is a specialization of function, copyable_function, ormove_only_function, or function_ref. Each argument of the invocation of x evaluated as part of the invocation of t may alias an argument in the same position in the invocation of t that has the same type, even if the corresponding parameter is not of reference type.
